texts.orig: /2022/09/02/pxe-boot-netboot.xyz-on-a-mikrotik-router/
texts.text: /2022/09/02/pxe-boot-netboot.xyz-on-a-mikrotik-router/

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: fedora
texts.text: fedora

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: linux
texts.text: linux

texts.text: mikrotik

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: networking
texts.text: networking

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: pxe
texts.text: pxe

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The first RFCs for  PXE , or preboot execution environment, showed up in June 1981 and it's still a popular tool today. It enables computers to boot up and download some software that runs early in the boot process.
texts.text: The first RFCs for  PXE , or preboot execution environment, showed up in June 1981 and it's still a popular tool today. It enables computers to boot up and download some software that runs early in the boot process.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Although PXE has been with us for ages, it's still extremely relevant today:
texts.text: Although PXE has been with us for ages, it's still extremely relevant today:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='Provisioning:'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='Provisioning:'>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='Rescue:'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='Rescue:'>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='Validation:'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='Validation:'>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='Ephemeral OS:'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='Ephemeral OS:'>]

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: A good friend of mine started a project to take PXE booting to the next level.
texts.text: A good friend of mine started a project to take PXE booting to the next level.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Enter netboot.xyz
texts.text: Enter netboot.xyz

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Most of the PXE deployments I've used in the past were restricted to a company's internal network for specfic uses. These deployments often served as a provisioning method.
texts.text: Most of the PXE deployments I've used in the past were restricted to a company's internal network for specfic uses. These deployments often served as a provisioning method.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Although the actual mechanisms for booting machines via PXE are not difficult, writing the backend scripts and creating keyboard-friendly menus is challenging. One of my favorite people on the planet,  Ant Messerli , started the  netboot.xyz  project several years ago.
texts.text: Although the actual mechanisms for booting machines via PXE are not difficult, writing the backend scripts and creating keyboard-friendly menus is challenging. One of my favorite people on the planet,  Ant Messerli , started the  netboot.xyz  project several years ago.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: What does netboot.xyz do for you? For one, you don't need to write your own menu scripts. All you do is PXE boot and use the menus already available on the site. You can even add your own in  netboot.xyz's GitHub repository
texts.text: What does netboot.xyz do for you? For one, you don't need to write your own menu scripts. All you do is PXE boot and use the menus already available on the site. You can even add your own in  netboot.xyz's GitHub repository

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The site relies on  ipxe , an open source boot firmware. There's no need to compile your own ipxe binary. netboot.xyz offers  pre-built ipxe binaries  that already connect you to netboot.xyz on the first boot!
texts.text: The site relies on  ipxe , an open source boot firmware. There's no need to compile your own ipxe binary. netboot.xyz offers  pre-built ipxe binaries  that already connect you to netboot.xyz on the first boot!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Here's what you'll see from netboot.xyz on your first boot:
texts.text: Here's what you'll see from netboot.xyz on your first boot:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Animation of selecting menu items from netboot.xyz
texts.text: Animation of selecting menu items from netboot.xyz

texts.label: title
texts.orig: PXE ingredients
texts.text: PXE ingredients

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Now that netboot.xyz did the hard part, what's left? A PXE environment requires a few items:
texts.text: Now that netboot.xyz did the hard part, what's left? A PXE environment requires a few items:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: DHCP server
texts.text: DHCP server

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: TFTP server
texts.text: TFTP server

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The DHCP server normally tells the machine about its IP address, gateway, DNS servers and more. However, we need it to provide two extra pieces of information:
texts.text: The DHCP server normally tells the machine about its IP address, gateway, DNS servers and more. However, we need it to provide two extra pieces of information:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: The server running a TFTP daemon
texts.text: The server running a TFTP daemon

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: The filename to request
texts.text: The filename to request

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The boot process for a machine on your network will go something like this:
texts.text: The boot process for a machine on your network will go something like this:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Machine makes a DHCP request
texts.text: Machine makes a DHCP request

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Your DHCP server replies with the usual IP information plus a server IP and filename for the PXE software
texts.text: Your DHCP server replies with the usual IP information plus a server IP and filename for the PXE software

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Machine sets its IP, gateway, netmask, and DNS
texts.text: Machine sets its IP, gateway, netmask, and DNS

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Machine downloads the PXE software from the server provided by the DHCP server
texts.text: Machine downloads the PXE software from the server provided by the DHCP server

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: PXE software runs on the machine
texts.text: PXE software runs on the machine

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Mikrotik PXE configuration
texts.text: Mikrotik PXE configuration

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Let's update the DHCP server configuration first. Log into your Mikrotik router via ssh and add configuration to your DHCP server's network configuration
texts.text: Let's update the DHCP server configuration first. Log into your Mikrotik router via ssh and add configuration to your DHCP server's network configuration

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
[major@hexs] > /ip/dhcp-server/
[major@hexs] /ip/dhcp-server> 
[major@hexs] /ip/dhcp-server/network> print
Columns: ADDRESS, GATEWAY, DNS-SERVER
# ADDRESS          GATEWAY       DNS-SERVER  
0 192.168.10.0/24  192.168.10.1  192.168.10.1
[major@hexs] /ip/dhcp-server/network> set next-server=192.168.10.1 boot-file-name=pxeboot numbers=0
texts.text:
[major@hexs] > /ip/dhcp-server/
[major@hexs] /ip/dhcp-server> 
[major@hexs] /ip/dhcp-server/network> print
Columns: ADDRESS, GATEWAY, DNS-SERVER
# ADDRESS          GATEWAY       DNS-SERVER  
0 192.168.10.0/24  192.168.10.1  192.168.10.1
[major@hexs] /ip/dhcp-server/network> set next-server=192.168.10.1 boot-file-name=pxeboot numbers=0

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Great. Now our DHCP server will tell new machines where to find their PXE image. Now we need to get our PXE boot image. Most of my machines support UEFI, so I use the  UEFI DHCP image . Upload the image to the mikrotik however you prefer. I normally use FTP or the web interface.
texts.text: Great. Now our DHCP server will tell new machines where to find their PXE image. Now we need to get our PXE boot image. Most of my machines support UEFI, so I use the  UEFI DHCP image . Upload the image to the mikrotik however you prefer. I normally use FTP or the web interface.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: My PXE image is stored on the Mikrotik as
texts.text: My PXE image is stored on the Mikrotik as

texts.label: code
texts.orig: /netboot.xyz/netboot.xyz.efi
texts.text: /netboot.xyz/netboot.xyz.efi

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: . Now we can set configure the Mikrotik's built-in FTP server:
texts.text: . Now we can set configure the Mikrotik's built-in FTP server:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
[major@hexs] > /ip tftp
add ip-addresses=192.168.10.0/24 real-filename=\
    /netboot.xyz/netboot.xyz.efi req-filename=.*
[major@hexs] > /ip tftp settings
set max-block-size=8192
texts.text:
[major@hexs] > /ip tftp
add ip-addresses=192.168.10.0/24 real-filename=\
    /netboot.xyz/netboot.xyz.efi req-filename=.*
[major@hexs] > /ip tftp settings
set max-block-size=8192

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: These settings enable TFTP access for anything on my LAN. Also, my PXE image from netboot.xyz is returned no matter what is in the request.
texts.text: These settings enable TFTP access for anything on my LAN. Also, my PXE image from netboot.xyz is returned no matter what is in the request.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Now it's time for a quick test! On Fedora, you can install a
texts.text: Now it's time for a quick test! On Fedora, you can install a

texts.label: code
texts.orig: tftp
texts.text: tftp

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: client by running
texts.text: client by running

texts.label: code
texts.orig: dnf install tftp
texts.text: dnf install tftp

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
❯ tftp 192.168.10.1 -v -m binary -c get pxeboot
mode set to octet
Connected to 192.168.10.1 (192.168.10.1), port 69
getting from 192.168.10.1:pxeboot to pxeboot [octet]
Received 1074688 bytes in 0.6 seconds [14810621 bit/s]
texts.text:
❯ tftp 192.168.10.1 -v -m binary -c get pxeboot
mode set to octet
Connected to 192.168.10.1 (192.168.10.1), port 69
getting from 192.168.10.1:pxeboot to pxeboot [octet]
Received 1074688 bytes in 0.6 seconds [14810621 bit/s]

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Awesome! Let's make sure we downloaded everything correctly:
texts.text: Awesome! Let's make sure we downloaded everything correctly:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# Check the software downloaded from TFTP
❯ sha256sum pxeboot                    
ef4b7d62d360bd8b58a3e83dfa87f8c645d459340554ce4ad66c0ef341fc3653  pxeboot

# Check our original file
❯ sha256sum ~/Downloads/netboot.xyz.efi
ef4b7d62d360bd8b58a3e83dfa87f8c645d459340554ce4ad66c0ef341fc3653  /home/major/Downloads/netboot.xyz.efi
texts.text:
# Check the software downloaded from TFTP
❯ sha256sum pxeboot                    
ef4b7d62d360bd8b58a3e83dfa87f8c645d459340554ce4ad66c0ef341fc3653  pxeboot

# Check our original file
❯ sha256sum ~/Downloads/netboot.xyz.efi
ef4b7d62d360bd8b58a3e83dfa87f8c645d459340554ce4ad66c0ef341fc3653  /home/major/Downloads/netboot.xyz.efi

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Now your systems on your local network can PXE boot using netboot.xyz! During the boot routine, you may need to press a key (usually F12, F11, F2, or maybe DEL) to bring up a boot selection menu. Pick the PXE or network boot option (choose IPv4 if asked) and boot!
texts.text: Now your systems on your local network can PXE boot using netboot.xyz! During the boot routine, you may need to press a key (usually F12, F11, F2, or maybe DEL) to bring up a boot selection menu. Pick the PXE or network boot option (choose IPv4 if asked) and boot!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: During the boot, your machine will boot the locally downloaded PXE image and it will automatically call out to netboot.xyz for menu selections. Scroll through the menus, choose your image, and enjoy! 🤓
texts.text: During the boot, your machine will boot the locally downloaded PXE image and it will automatically call out to netboot.xyz for menu selections. Scroll through the menus, choose your image, and enjoy! 🤓
